channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: How the Supreme Court’s State Legislature Case Could Change Elections
item.description: Races in state legislatures are often quiet and turn on local issues like roads or schools. But a Supreme Court case could give these legislative bodies nearly absolute power over federal elections.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Veronica Klinefelt, left, a Democratic candidate for the Michigan State Senate, speaking with Jennifer Trupp, a teacher, last week in Eastpointe, Mich. Democrats see the district as crucial for taking back the chamber.

item.title: Evangelicals Find a Way Forward With Herschel Walker
item.description: The embattled G.O.P. candidate reportedly paid for an ex-girlfriend’s abortion, but conservatives have learned to tolerate the behavior of those who advance their cause.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Dias
item.media:description: Herschel Walker, the former football star and Republican nominee for U.S. Senate, speaking at an event in Perry, Ga.

item.title: Election Workers Face an Obstacle Course to Reach the Midterms
item.description: Officials coordinating the November vote vow to be ready. But lawsuits, demands for voting records and unbending believers that elections are rigged are making it harder.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wines
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Miami-Dade County election workers counting ballots during Florida’s primary election in Doral, Fla., in August.

item.title: How Colleen Hoover Rose to Rule the Best-Seller List
item.description: With legions of devoted fans and a knack for high-voltage emotional drama, Hoover has sold more than 20 million books. And she’s done it her way.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Jake Dockins for The New York Times
item.media:description: Colleen Hoover at home in Texas this month. “She’s defying the laws of how the market works,” said an industry analyst.

item.title: Inside Mark Zuckerberg’s Metaverse Struggles
item.description: Meta’s push to develop virtual and augmented reality technology has had a bumpy year.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Sheera Frenkel and Kevin Roose
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, introducing the Oculus Quest virtual-reality headset in 2019.

item.title: As Warehouses Multiply, Some California Cities Say: Enough
item.description: Several municipalities in California’s Inland Empire have halted new projects to study their impact on pollution and congestion, but labor and business groups have warned that moratoriums could cost the region tax revenue and jobs.
item.dc:creator: Kurtis Lee and Alex Welsh
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: A warehouse abuts a residential street in Colton, Calif.

item.title: That Reusable Trader Joe’s Bag? It’s Rescuing an Indian Industry.
item.description: India’s deep-rooted jute industry has struggled for decades, undercut by cheaper synthetics. Now its bags are a sought-after biodegradable alternative.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Hukumchand Jute Mill in the Indian state of West Bengal, where the country’s jute industry is concentrated.

item.title: Justice Jackson Joins the Supreme Court, and the Debate Over Originalism
item.description: In arguments in a voting rights case, the new justice said history must inform constitutional interpretation, making a liberal case for an idea often associated with conservatives.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson, center, demonstrated in her second day of hearing arguments on the Supreme Court that she believes originalism can require liberal outcomes.

item.title: ‘Eye of Sauron’: The Dazzling Solar Tower in the Israeli Desert
item.description: Looming over a remote village in the Negev, the Ashalim solar plant is, for some, a marvel of green technology. For others, it’s a boondoggle and an eyesore.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Amit Elkayam
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shepherds near the Ashalim solar station. Completed in 2019, the tower generates enough electricity to power tens of thousands of homes.

item.title: Boris Johnson Inc. Is About to Go Public
item.description: Following in the footsteps of his predecessors, the former prime minister is likely to earn huge sums as an author and speaker, just as the lecture circuit booms back to life.
item.dc:creator: David Segal
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former British prime minister, could earn as much as $250,000 per speech, executives at speakers’ bureaus say.

item.title: What I’ve Learned in 60 Years of Listening to the Philharmonic
item.description: When Anthony Tommasini was a young, aspiring musician, he made his first forays into the orchestra’s concert hall. He realized it would not do.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Tommasini
item.media:description: Leonard Bernstein conducting the New York Philharmonic at the opening of Philharmonic Hall in 1962. That first night was “was a near-disaster, acoustically,” a Times critic wrote back then.

item.title: The Midterms Aren’t the Only Thing That’s Looming
item.description: Borders all over the world are in dispute, and they are not all geographical.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.media:description: An unfinished section of the border wall near Roma, Texas.

item.title: Joe Biden Knows How to Use Donald Trump
item.description: A lot of politicians would have vied with Trump to make the election about them.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein

item.title: Xi Jinping Is a Captive of the Communist Party Too
item.description: It may appear that Xi Jinping has taken over the party, but it’s the other way around.
item.dc:creator: Kerry Brown
item.media:credit: Noel Celis/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images

item.title: My Elders in Pakistan Predicted Calamity. Now It’s Here.
item.description: This is what happens when the floodwaters come.
item.dc:creator: Ibrahim Buriro
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times

item.title: The Exploitative Anti-Blackness of Kanye West
item.description: By wearing a “White Lives Matter” shirt, Kanye West gave white supremacists a boost.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow

item.title: How I Fell In Love With Loretta Lynn
item.description: Loretta Lynn was complicated. Love is, too.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl

item.title: Why Must Puerto Ricans Always Be Resilient?
item.description: We are tired of celebrating our ability to endure, of being creative in the face of adversity.
item.dc:creator: Yarimar Bonilla
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left, Alejandro Granadillo/Associated Press; Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times; Alejandro Granadillo/Associated Press; Ricardo Arduengo/Reuters
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left, Salinas Beach in Puerto Rico; a power outage in Yauco; a house in Salinas; Nereida Batista at her home in Toa Baja.

item.title: The Supreme Court Could Decide the Fate of America’s Pregnant Pigs
item.description: The Supreme Court should allow a California law restricting gestation crates to stand
item.dc:creator: Mark Essig
item.media:credit: Aitor Garmendia/World Press Photo, via Associated Press

item.title: The Cooling Economy
item.description: The job market is still strong, but the long-expected slowdown has begun.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman

item.title: Revisiting Baldwin vs. Buckley
item.description: Nicholas Buccola talks about “The Fire Is Upon Us,” and Lydia Millet discusses “The Children’s Bible.”
item.media:credit: From left: Dave Pickoff/Associated Press; Associated Press
item.media:description: The 1965 debate between James Baldwin and William F. Buckley Jr. at the Cambridge Union was a crucial battle in the fight over civil rights.

item.title: ‘The Run-Up’: Can Democrats Catch up to Years of Republican Unity?
item.description: The overturning of Roe v. Wade has given Democrats a rallying issue to mobilize around before the midterms. Can they catch up to years of Republican unity?
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team
item.media:credit: Emil Lippe for The New York Times

item.title: Do You Have Questions About the Social Security COLA? We Want to Hear From You
item.description: Reporters and editors working on our coverage of Social Security will find the answers.

item.title: After Racist Comments, Los Angeles City Council President Faces Calls to Resign
item.description: In a leaked recording of a meeting last year, she mocked Indigenous immigrants and the Black child of a fellow council member.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler and Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Al Seib/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Nury Martinez, president of the Los Angeles City Council.

item.title: Mets Season Ends With Wild-Card Loss to Padres
item.description: Stuck in the wild-card round despite 101 wins, the Mets had no answers for San Diego, which took two of three games to advance to a division series.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Michelle Farsi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asked to keep the Mets’ season alive, Chris Bassitt lasted only four innings on Sunday. He allowed three earned runs and took the loss.

item.title: What Is Indigenous Peoples’ Day and How Is It Celebrated?
item.description: Many cities and states are observing the day. Here’s some of the history behind it.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Fatima Garcia of the group Danza Azteca Guadalupana dances during an event celebrating Indigenous Peoples’ Day in Austin, Texas, in 2021.

item.title: Flu Shot: What to Know About Side Effects, Protection and Timing
item.description: And everything else you’ve been wondering about this annual vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh

item.title: The Joy Workout
item.description: Six research-backed moves to improve your mood
item.dc:creator: Kelly McGonigal

item.title: Gut Healing Is TikTok’s Latest Trend. Does It Work?
item.description: Despite what social media might have you believe, there is no overnight shortcut to better digestive health.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: What is E.M.D.R.? Understanding the Trauma Therapy Practice
item.description: The once-experimental trauma treatment has become increasingly popular. Here’s how the therapy works.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Sophie Park
item.category: The Body Keeps the Score: Brain, Mind and Body in the Healing of Trauma (Book)
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times

item.title: Art That Rose Through the Cracks
item.description: Three exemplary exhibitions draw attention to public space, from community gardens to rooftop sculptures.
item.dc:creator: John Vincler

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
